title: When will the World Health Organization (WHO) report more than 35 million confirmed cases of COVID-19 for the Europe Region?
preds: I think this happened the other day.
My math as of 1/31 data says 2/26/21 it should hit it.
Europe has already hit 32 million cases as of 31 Jan. With the new more virulent strains it is going to hit 35 million before 28 Feb 21.

Increasing my probability for hitting 35M before Feb 28th further. At the current rate of 1.5M new cases / week, unless the vaccine(s) result in a sharp reduction over the next week or so, we'd have crossed the 35M total case counts in Europe.
With 33.7M confirmed cases reported as of 29 Jan 2021 and a daily rate around 200,000 cases, there should be over 35M confirmed cases within the week.

Graphics show that number of confirmed cases has reached a plateau in Europe since last November. The apparition of the new variants is compensated by the distribution of vaccines (many of which are also effective against the variants) and the firm lockdown policies implemented in many European countries. Thus, it is almost impossible that the number of confirmed cases pass 35 million.
Based on current amounts and average rates of increases should hit this amount on 2/24/21.

Actually lower my confidence on the <Feb 28th Interval
1. Based on the decrease in week-to-week case count case count rate of 128K/day  looking at the
2. There is some probability of the virus being contained/slowed down due to the vaccine
We're already seeing 33.2M cases as of Jan 26th. The probability of confirmed cases not crossing 35M in a month, i.e by Feb 28th is <1%. Updating results accordingly
based on current trends up to 1/26 it should hit the goal around 2/25.

1/22 = 31,659,231 cases reported at a daily rate over 18 days of 255,552 new per day. Could reach the threshold in 14 days at the current rate.
1/4 = 27,059,283 European cases.
1/3 = 26,881,446 European cases.
1/1 = 26,490,335 European cases.
based on recent rates they should hit this total in 31 days.... around 2/20.  (assuming recent trends continue)

5.5m to go running at 200k per day. 45 days to end Feb would give 9m extra cases.  Only need 122k cases to get to 35m by end Feb. Given current position hard to drop the average that far that quickly.
Almost at 30 million cases on WHO Dashboard as of now — sadly it’s a safe bet that Europe will reach 35 million cases before end of February.
Cases would have to average half of what they are from today until the end of February for this to not happen before the end of February.

1. Model case count as an exponential growth
2. Past doubling rates in Europe
    - 13M  to 26M - 08.57 Weeks 
    - 10M  to 20M - 06.00 Weeks
    - 05M  to 10M - 04.71 Weeks
    - 2.5M to 05M - 29.00 Weeks
3. What is the threshold doubling rate required to hit 35M cases?
     - On Feb 28th: 16.54 Weeks
     - On April 30th: 40.16 Weeks
     - On June 30th: 57.71 Weeks
4. Effects of Vaccination Rate will slow doubling rate. Effects of new strain are decreasing already.
    Unsure of the efficacy of vaccine rate? Will the slow down be fast enough to drop below an effective doubling of 16 weeks from the current 8.6 weeks before Feb end? Unsure..
    We have seen a doubling rate of ~29 weeks even without the vaccine coming into play during the summers in Europe.
5. Prediction Probability distribution
    Peak at "By Feb 28th" with not too fast a drop-off on future dates References:
- Our World In Data for Europe Total Cases: https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&country=~Europe&region=World&casesMetric=true&interval=total&smoothing=0&pickerMetric=total_cases&pickerSort=desc
- Threshold Doubling Rate Calculation: https://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=ln%282%29%2F%28ln%2835%2F26.1%29%2F24.43%29
- Duration in Weeks from Jan 10th to Threshold Date: https://www.wolframalpha.com/input/?i=total+weeks+from+january+10th+2021+to+june+30th+2021

today: 28,986,854
The number of cases is globally stable over the last few months and is not decreasing contrary to my last prediction.
Current wave is tapering off very slowly. Vaccine rollout probably won't be fast enough to change that. Currently looks to me like it is on-track to cross 35m in mid February.

Currently the European Area (as of 5 Jan) has 27,282,019 cases confirmed. The current rate of new infections is averaging about 250,00-300,000 per day for the last month. Assuming a better case scenario of only 200,000 per day then the case incidence will reach 35,000,000 in 39 days (13 Feb). For the case load to not reach 35 Million before 1 Mar the total number of cases would need to be less than 143,000 per day on average. No single day rate has been below this since early October, let alone the average. It seems unlikely that the case load could drop so quickly regardless of a vaccine.

1/4 = 27,059,283 European cases.
1/3 = 26,881,446 European cases.
1/1 = 26,490,335 European cases.
To reach the threshold there would need to be 8,118,554 more cases.
To reach that by 28 Feb would require daily cases of 142,430 in the next 57 days.
The daily rate is now 189,649 which exceeds the amount needed by a lot.
At the current daily rate, the threshold will be reached by mid-Feb.
GAME OVER.

About 8.1 million cases left and 300,000 cases per day. Leaves 27 days, so very confident on February. https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2020-03-01..latest&country=~Europe&region=World&casesMetric=true&interval=smoothed&perCapita=true&smoothing=7&pickerMetric=total_cases&pickerSort=desc

1/3 = 26,881,446 European cases.
1/1 = 26,490,335 European cases.
To reach the threshold there would need to be 8,118,554 more cases.
To reach that by 28 Feb would require daily cases of 142,430 in the next 57 days.
The daily rate is now 195,555 which exceeds the amount needed by a lot.
At the current daily rate, the threshold will be reached by  mid-Feb.
GAME OVER.

1/1 = 26,490,335 European cases.
To reach the threshold there would need to be 8,509,665 more cases.
To reach that by 28 Feb would require daily cases of 144,231 in the next 59 days.
The daily rate is now 287,431 which exceeds the amount needed by a lot. 
At the current daily rate, the threshold will be reached by end of January.
GAME OVER.

About 27m cases currently reported.  About 200k cases being reported each day.  At this rate it will take 40 days to reach 35m which is mid feb.  Given we are hitting a high infection period due to new strands it’s probably going to be quicker.

Finally got around to checking my numbers.  As I used to remind my students, asking the wrong question is an excellent way to get the wrong answer.  I've been off by a factor of five or ten owing to precisely the sort of sloppiness I used to berate them for.  Serves me right.

They haven't got long to flatten this curve, however the pressure to do so in the New Year is going to be immense given the likely total overwhelming of many health systems. It remains to be seen whether Christmas gatherings will add more to the total than the school holidays take away. I would put a higher probability on effective lock-down than business as usual, for much of the Europe region anyway. Nevertheless, the chances of never reaching 25 million seem quite slim.

12/29 = 25,628,041 European cases.
To reach the threshold there would need to be 9,371,959 more cases.
To reach that by 28 Feb would require daily cases of 151,160 in the next 62 days.
The Weekly rate is now 1,485,004 new cases for a daily rate of 212,143 which exceeds the amount needed by a lot. If the daily rate slows by a great deal, it may take until April to reach the threshold of 35M.
We can't vaccinate fast enough to prevent this.
Going all-in that folks can't act like grown-ups and keep their distance over x-mas and new years, and that this seals the deal on this one.

New and highly contagious strain of the Corona Virus has come out of London (1). Possibly one of the worst cities to have this originate given it's position as a hub for the UK and Heathrow is still very much open.  1. https://www.npr.org/2020/12/20/948560655/we-cannot-continue-with-christmas-u-k-tightens-rules-as-new-covid-variant-spread

Over last 3 weeks, the weekly new case average is stable ~1.6m cases/week. It is not dropping at all. 
We should be prepared for a harsh winter

Europe's a big place and it seems despite some localized spikes being controlled within countries, the 7 day average hasn't been below 200k since Oct 25 (using WHO data). From today, an average daily new case count of 170k is enough to deliver bucket 2 on the last day, while it would seem likely we will start getting ahead with the vaccine, a few things to balance that optimism; - Vaccine roll outs are anticipating on hitting the general public in early 2021
- All the vaccines being rolled out across most of Europe are 2 doses and there has been no work put in to their ability to suppress transmitability, it is possible that every vaccinated person could become a spreader. 
- All this optimism, on top of lockdown/bubble/social distancing fatigue will create complacency and Christmas is coming. Tragically, I expect this daily count to stay above 200k new cases per day at least until mid-to-late Jan, which looks ominous.

I looked at last 2 weeks total additions and extrapolated into the number of days it would take to reach from now. Looks like across Europe over the last 2 weeks there were on the order of 168,298 new cases per day. This gives me a rough estimate on how to place the expected outcome.

Increasing rate of testing might play a huge role 
15M left so about 75k cases per day
Europe has it under control now. Expecting the average daily new cases to do down to ~120k/day by December end

18M per today, and it seems that the trend in going down a little. Vaccines should become available soon enough. I was just wondering about this question and the Tokio Olympics question. If the games are going to take place, something must be done long before July 2021.
Practically, if in EU there are 35M confirmed cases between May--June; then there can't be games!
Current numbers for the rest of the duration would be end of bin 2, but the trend is down, and vaccines will be available by the end of this year.
Vaccine is just round the corner.

The current wave is ablating, and I'm guessing it will get us to around 25m cases by the end of the year. There's time for that to grow a bit, but with vaccination set to roll out in force from ~March-May I think there's a good chance that if Europe hasn't hit 35m by the end of February, it won't do so later.
New vaccine developments and dropping rate of daily cases in Europe is making me more optimistic.
It is likely that EU governments will continue to enact policies to slow the spread of the virus.  This should mitigate some of the virus fatigue.

Governments are taking stern measures currently to limit the spread but this is a tortoise and hare situation and once the lockdowns are eased all countries will experience new waves and the value of the lockdown will decrease as everyone becomes more and more inured against trying to quell the pandemic. As potential vaccines roll out more will become infected.

Cases are still high in Europe, lockdowns still need to bring benefits where they’ve been introduced, but countries’ economies are hurting so some countries will elect to allow fairly high transmission. I estimate an average on 180k new cases daily through winter, so around 120 days from now, we should see 35 million cases confirmed. A vaccine may make a dent in those numbers, but high risk people will be prioritised, so I expect it to make little difference within this timeframe. So, my prediction is around 11 March 2021.

The number of confirmed cases in Europe is currently 13,576,687.  The reported daily increase was reported to be 193,395 as of Nov 10. This represents a lower low which indicates a trend reversal or a flattening of the curve. Given the kinetics of the last peak and the current phase and season, it is most likely a flattening with highs around 325000, reaching 35,000,000 Jan 16 and lows around 190000 reaching 35,000,000 Feb 27.

If they maintained around 250,000 cases a day (around where they're at now) they would hit 35 million in early February. If they averaged half that or 125,000 cases a day they would hit 35 million in early May. I see where they're at currently as the likely higher end of the range, and about half as the likely low end of the range. So I'm assigning February through May buckets the highest probabilities.
